text.b: M E M O R A N D U M
Special Land Use & Final Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

page.text: (SP 14-02-04) to subdivide former school administration building site into 36
individual lots for detached single-family dwellings at 1123 Lexington Blvd.
At the February 11, 2014 regular meeting, the Planning Commission approved a special land
use permit and preliminary special redevelopment site condominium plan for the above
referenced project (SP 14-02-04). The approval was conditioned upon various issues being
addressed within a final special redevelopment site condominium plan. The original staff report
and memorandum of approval are attached for background purposes.
As required under the preliminary approval, the petitioner has submitted a final special
redevelopment site condominium plan for the proposed project. The number of lots and lot sizes
as shown on the final plan remain unchanged from the preliminary site condominium plan.
As required by the Planning Commission, included with the final site condominium plan is a
traffic impact study for the proposed project conducted by the engineering firm Fleis &
Vandenbrink. Their study concludes that: (a) all intersection approaches and movements will
operate acceptably at a level-of-service “D” or better during peak periods; (b) the proposed
development would have a negligible impact on the road network; and (c) the proposed site
access points with Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue will operate acceptably.
A proposed phasing schedule was also submitted that would be included as part of the required
special redevelopment agreement to be approved by the City Commission. The phasing
schedule would divide the project into 3 separate phases. The two new streets, Arbor Avenue
and Thistle Lane, and all underground utilities would be constructed as part of the second phase
The Planning and Engineering Departments both recommend than any approved phasing
schedule include the installation of all streets, street trees, and utilities as part of a single phase.
Otherwise, the city could be left with dead-end streets and utilities that are not looped if the
project is not pursued to completion and stopped after either the first or second phase. The
Planning Commission should also determine if the landscaped berm along the west lot
boundary should be completed as part of this phase, or if it could be installed in separate
The phasing schedule also includes the location for a temporary sales trailer with access to
Marais Avenue. The Planning Commission should also determine if the proposed trailer location
is acceptable or if another location is more suitable.
The Planning Commission may allow deviations from applicable Zoning Ordinance standards as
part any Special Redevelopment project under §770-87 (D)(2) if there are features designed
into the plan that can be demonstrated by the applicant, and deemed adequate enough by the
Commission, to protect users of the project and all surrounding land uses, as well as the
general public health, safety, and welfare. However, no items on the proposed site
condominium plan deviate from required standards of the Zoning Ordinance. The proposed lot
sizes and building envelopes would comply with the bulk and area standards for the One Family
If the final special land use permit and special redevelopment site condominium plan are
approved by the Planning Commission, the petitioner would have authorization to submit a
special redevelopment agreement for review and approval by the City Commission under § 770-
87 (G) of the Zoning Ordinance. Staff recommends that any special land use permit approved
by the Planning Commission be subject to all streets, utilities, and other right-of-way
improvements being completed before any building permits are issued for individual dwellings
on either Arbor Avenue or Thistle Lane.
The Planning Commission may grant, at its discretion, final plan approval for a Special
Redevelopment project with or without conditions. Following the required public hearing, the
Commission may approve, approve with conditions, or deny a final Special Redevelopment
plan. The basis for the Planning Commission’s decision in the case of a special land use
request is found in §770-11 (C), Basis of Determinations, which reads as follows:

text.i: The Planning Commission shall review the proposed special land use in terms of the standards stated within
this Ordinance and shall establish that such use and the proposed location:
(a) Will be harmonious and in accordance with the general objectives or any specific objectives of the
Master Plan.
(b) Will be designed, constructed, operated, and maintained so as to be harmonious and appropriate in
appearance with the existing or intended character of the general vicinity and will not change the
essential character of the area.
(c) Will not be hazardous or disturbing to existing uses or uses reasonably anticipated in the future.
(d) Will be an improvement in relation to property in the immediate vicinity and to the City as a whole.
(e) Will be served adequately by essential public services and facilities or that the persons responsible for
the establishment of the proposed use will provide adequately any such service or facility.
Will not create excessive additional public costs and will not be detrimental to the economic welfare of
the City.
(g) Will be consistent with the intent and purposes of this Ordinance, and comply with all applicable
provisions and standards, which are established for said use by this Ordinance and other applicable
codes.

page.text: The qualifications for treatment of a Special Redevelopment project are found in § 770-87,
Special Redevelopment Projects, subparagraph (B)(1), which reads as follows:

text.i: The applicant shall demonstrate compliance § 770-11 (C), Basis of Determinations, for a special land use
permit, as well as the following:
(a) The existing structures on the property were initially constructed for hotel and/or motel use, public
schools, or other sites identified by the Planning Commission as possible for a special redevelopment
district.
(b) For hotels and/or motels, public schools and other sites as identified by the Planning Commission, the
applicant proposes to redevelop the property by removing or making material modifications,
discontinuing the existing use(s) on the property, and establishing a new use consistent with the intent
and provisions of this section.
(c) A recognizable and material benefit to the City will result from the redevelopment.
(d) The proposed use and improvements shall not result in an unreasonable increase in the need for or
burden upon public services, facilities, streets and utilities.
(e) The proposed use and improvements will result in an advantageous economic impact upon surrounding
properties.
The current structures on the property are materially nonconforming and/or the use is obsolete. For the
purposes of this subsection, obsolete are those hotels and motels existing or built prior to the adoption
of the chapter, those schools identified by the Royal Oak School Board as obsolete and those
properties identified by the Planning Commission as special redevelopment sites.
(g) The proposed use and improvements shall be consistent with the goals and policies of the Master Plan
and consistent with the intent of this section, as set forth in Subsection A, above.
(h) The proposed use is compatible with adjacent and nearby residential uses.

page.text: cc: James V. Clarke, Robertson Brothers Co.
Brad W. Brickel, PE, Nowak & Fraus PLLC
Shawn Lewis-Lakins, Royal Oak School District

i.b: It is recommended that the petitioner or a representative attend the June 10, 2014 Planning Commission
meeting. The meeting starts at 7:30 p.m. in the City Commission Chambers on the 3rd floor of City Hall.

text.b: M E M O R A N D U M

page.text: SP 14-02-04 – Final Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan to
subdivide former school administration building site into 36 individual lots for
detached single-family dwellings at 1123 Lexington Blvd. (parcel no. 25-04-351-
The above referenced final special redevelopment site condominium plan is scheduled for
consideration by the Planning Commission at its meeting of June 10, 2014. Should the Planning
Commission approve the associated special land use permit and wish to consider final approval
of the final special redevelopment site condominium plan, the Planning Department
1. The petitioner shall prepare and submit a special redevelopment agreement for the
proposed project and final site condominium plan for review by the City Attorney and
approval by the City Commission. The final site condominium plan and special
redevelopment agreement shall also contain the phasing schedule and temporary sales
trailer location as approved by the Planning Commission.
2. All driveways shall have access to only Arbor Avenue, Marais Avenue, or Thistle Lane. No
new driveways to Lexington Boulevard shall be permitted. Driveways for all lots adjacent to
Lexington Boulevard shall be placed along each lot’s south side lot line.
3. All utilities and improvements to the public rights-of-way shall be in accordance with the
specifications and standards of the City Engineer, including, but not limited to: repair and/or
replacement of existing sidewalks on Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue adjacent to
the site; connecting storm water and sanitary sewers to the adjacent Oakland County drains;
and looping proposed water mains into an existing the existing water main on Marais
Avenue. All electrical, telephone, cable television, and similar lines shall be placed
4. Compliance with all other applicable provisions the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 770
including § 770-14, Site Condominium Project Regulations), the Subdivision Regulations
Ordinance (Chapter 658), and the Michigan Land Division Act (Public Act 288 of 1967, as
5. A performance bond for each individual building/unit shall be posted in an amount to be
6. The final special redevelopment site condominium plan shall meet all other Code and
Ordinance requirements, as determined by the Building Official and/or City Engineer, prior
to issuance of any building permit. Such requirements include, but are not limited to, the
Michigan Building Code and the city’s Stormwater Detention Ordinance (Chapter 644).
Unless specifically addressed in the development agreement.
7. All of the following items shall be completed, as determined by the development agreement
and city requirements; streets, curbs, gutters, and sidewalks; street trees; utilities and other
right-of-way improvements, whether public or private; landscaped berms; and other items
determined necessary and advisable by the Planning Commission.
cc: James V. Clarke, Robertson Brothers Co.
Brad W. Brickel, PE, Nowak & Fraus PLLC
Shawn Lewis-Lakins, Royal Oak School District

i.b: It is recommended that the petitioner or a representative attend the June 10, 2014 Planning Commission
meeting. The meeting starts at 7:30 p.m. in the City Commission Chambers on the 3rd floor of City Hall.

text.b: M E M O R A N D U M
Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium

page.text: Plan (SP 14-02-04) to subdivide former school administration building site into 36
individual lots for detached single-family dwellings at 1123 Lexington Blvd.
The Planning Commission, at its meeting on February 11, 2014, Approved a Special Land
Use Permit to subdivide the former school administration building site into 36 individual lots for
detached single-family dwellings at 1123 Lexington Blvd. (parcel no. 25-04-351-041).
At that same meeting, the Planning Commission Approved a Preliminary Special
Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan (SP 14-02-04) to subdivide the former school
administration building site into 36 individual lots for detached single-family dwellings at 1123
Lexington Blvd. (parcel no. 25-04-351-041), with the following contingencies:
1. An application for final special land use permit and special redevelopment site condominium
plan review shall be submitted within 6 months as required under § 770-87 (C)(4) of the
2. All future use of each individual lot shall be limited to detached single-family dwellings or
another permitted use listed under § 770-34 (B) of the Zoning Ordinance.
3. All lots on the final site condominium plan shall comply with the minimum required lot size
standards of the One Family Residential zoning district listed under § 770-34 (D)(1) to (3) of
4. All dwellings shall comply with the minimum required and maximum permitted area and bulk
regulations of the One Family Residential zoning district listed under § 770-34 (D)(4) to (9)
5. All accessory structures shall be placed within the rear yard of each lot and otherwise
comply with § 770-22 of the Zoning Ordinance. No dwelling shall have a front-loaded
6. All driveways shall have access to only Arbor Court or Marais Avenue. No new driveways to
Lexington Boulevard shall be permitted. Driveways for all lots adjacent to Lexington
Boulevard shall be placed along each lot’s south side lot line.
7. At least one large, deciduous canopy tree of a species listed in § 770-90 (K)(5) of the Zoning
Ordinance with a minimum caliper of 2.5 inches shall be placed in the right-of-way curb lawn
8. The proposed landscaped berm shown along west rear lot line within the petitioner’s
property boundaries shall be further detailed and identified on the final site condominium
plan in accordance with § 770-90 (D) of the Zoning Ordinance.
9. All utilities and improvements to the public rights-of-way shall be in accordance with the
specifications and standards of the City Engineer, including, but not limited to: repair and/or
replacement of existing sidewalks on Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue adjacent to
the site; connecting storm water and sanitary sewers to the adjacent Oakland County drains;
and looping proposed water mains into an existing the existing water main on Marais
Avenue. All electrical, telephone, cable television, and similar lines shall be placed
10. Compliance with all other applicable provisions the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 770
including § 770-14, Site Condominium Project Regulations), the Subdivision Regulations
Ordinance (Chapter 658), and the Michigan Land Division Act (Public Act 288 of 1967, as
11. As part of the application for final special land use permit and special redevelopment site
condominium plan review, the petitioner shall also prepare and submit the following:
a. A traffic study so that the costs to mitigate impacts can be assigned to the development
as determined necessary by the Planning Commission;
b. A construction staging plan for sales and/or construction trailers, off-street parking, etc.;
c. A special redevelopment agreement for the proposed project and final site condominium
plan for review by the City Attorney and approval by the City Commission.

text.b: An application for final review cannot be submitted until all contingencies have been
addressed and included as part of the revised plans.

page.text: cc: James V. Clarke, Robertson Brothers Co.
Brad W. Brickel, PE, Nowak & Fraus PLLC
Shawn Lewis-Lakins, Royal Oak School District

text.b: M E M O R A N D U M
Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium

page.text: Plan (SP 14-02-04) to subdivide former school administration building site into 36
individual lots for detached single-family dwellings at 1123 Lexington Blvd.
ARTICLE III Administration & Enforcement – § 770-14 Site Condominium Project
Regulations: This section provides design standards, review criteria, and approval
procedures for dividing property into individual lots for single-family dwellings as a site
condominium plan instead of a platted subdivision. Preliminary and final approval by the
Planning Commission is required for all site condominium plans and condominium
documents. All design standards and required improvements that apply to platted
subdivisions under Chapter 658, Subdivision Regulations, also apply to site condominium
ARTICLE IV Zone Regulations & General Provisions – § 770-48 Special Redevelopment:
This zoning district is intended for obsolete or nonconforming motels, school properties, or
other sites identified by the Planning Commission. This zoning district is intended to: allow
for redevelopment of these sites in accordance with their character and adaptability; provide
enhanced housing, employment, shopping, traffic circulation and recreational opportunities;

i.b: Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

page.text: and bring about a greater compatibility of design and use. All proposed uses in this zoning
district require a special land use permit and are subject to the criteria and standards set
ARTICLE V Special Provisions – § 770-87 Special Redevelopment Projects: This section
provides design standards, review criteria, and approval procedures for all projects in the
Special Redevelopment zoning district. All projects in the Special Redevelopment zoning
district require both a special land use permit approved by the Planning Commission and a
development agreement approved by the City Commission.
The Future Land Use Map from the city’s
future use for this property as “Public / Insti-
this site under the previous Master Plan
adopted in 1999.) According to the text of
the Master Plan these areas “… are

text.i: intended to accommodate such activities as
governmental and public buildings, schools,

page.text: buildings, schools, and certain parks and
A. Site Dimensions & Existing Use. The property is located at the southwest corner of
Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue and contains the administration building for
Royal Oak Public Schools. The parcel has 465 feet of frontage along Lexington
Boulevard and 695.04 feet of frontage along Marais Avenue. The parcel has 323,112
square feet of lot area or 7.42 acres and is zoned “Special Redevelopment.”
B. Proposed Use & Lot Sizes. The petitioner
proposes to demolish all existing structures
and then divide the parcel into 36 lots for
single-family dwellings as part of a site
condominium plan. Twelve lots would front on
Marais Avenue (1 to 12) while the rest would
front on a new street called Arbor Court (13 to
36). All interior lots would have a lot width of
50 feet, the minimum required in the One
corner lots would have a lot width of at least
60 feet, the minimum required under § 770-34 (D)(2). The table to the right lists the
proposed lot width, depth, and area for each lot according to the petitioner’s preliminary

i.b: Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

page.text: C. Density & Lot Sizes. According to §770-87 (D)(1), density for residential uses in a
Special Redevelopment project shall be determined by the Planning Commission based
on the petitioner demonstrating the following: consistency with the Master Plan;
innovative planning and design excellence; positive relationship to adjacent land uses;
adequate provision for pedestrian and vehicular safety; promotion of aesthetic beauty;
internal compatibility on the property; and adequate provisions to accommodate the
health, safety, and welfare of the users of the project.
The neighborhood to the south is zoned One Family Residential. The minimum lot size
standards required within the One Family Residential zoning district are 50 feet of width
for interior lots, 60 feet of width for corner lots, 100 feet of depth, and 6,000 square feet
of area under § 770-34 (D)(1) through (3). All of the lots proposed on the petitioner’s
preliminary site condominium plan would comply with these standards.
The neighborhood to the east is zoned One Family Large Lot Residential. The minimum
lot size standards required within the One Family Large Lot Residential zoning district
are 50 feet of width for interior lots, 70 feet of width for corner lots, 100 feet of depth, and
13,000 square feet of area under § 770-34 (D)(1) through (3). Only one of the lots
proposed on the petitioner’s preliminary site condominium plan would comply with these
D. Yard Setbacks & Lot Coverage. All building envelopes for the proposed dwellings
comply with the minimum required setbacks for single-family dwellings in either the One
Family Residential zoning district under § 770-34 (D)(5) through (7), or the One Family
Large Lot Residential zoning district under § 770-35 (D)(5) through (7). The proposed
building envelopes would result in approximate lot coverage percentages of between
15% and 24%, less than the maximum permitted total lot coverage of 30% allowed
under § 770-34 (D)(8) for lots with more than 6,000 square feet of lot area in the One
Family Residential zoning district, and for all lots in the One Family Large Lot Residential
E. Access, Parking, & Traffic Generation. All new lots would be accessed by a driveway to
either Arbor Court or Marais Avenue. Detached garages are proposed in the rear yards
of each lot. As proposed, the driveways and building envelopes for the garages would
comply with applicable standards in the Zoning Ordinance for off-street parking and
The proposed pattern of having all driveways on the same side of the dwelling on each
side of the street could limit the amount of on-street parking on Arbor Court. It could also
impede traffic circulation by not having sufficient yield areas where drivers can pull over
to avoid on-coming traffic when vehicles are parked on both sides of the street. These
problems could be avoided by alternating which sides of each interior lot driveways are
placed. For example, one lot could have a driveway along its south side lot line, while
the adjacent lot to the south could have a driveway along its north side lot line.
According to ITE’s Trip Generation Handbook, the Planning Department estimates that
36 detached single-family dwellings on 7.42 acres as proposed by the petitioner could
generate approximately 190 to 340 vehicle trips per day for any given weekday.
Approximately 230 to 360 trips could be generated on a Saturday with 200 to 310 trips

i.b: Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

page.text: F. Streets, Sidewalks, & Utilities. A 50-foot wide right-of-way for a new street, Arbor Court,
is proposed that would intersection with Lexington Boulevard along the site’s north lot
line. The street would extend southwards to the 60-foot Oakland County sewer
easement and then extend to the east to intersect with Marias Avenue. From the sewer
easement the street would continue southward and terminate at the south side lot line.
This dead end is required to provide access and frontage to lots 13 and 36 required
under both the Zoning and Subdivision Regulations Ordinances.
The street would consist of a 27-foot wide concrete pavement with curb and gutter. A 27-
foot wide curb-cut through the median of Lexington Boulevard is also proposed. Five-
foot sidewalks are proposed along both sides of the street. The sidewalks also extend
westward over the easement to the city-owned park along the west rear lot line.
The Engineering Department will require other upgrades to infrastructure and utilities as
part of the proposed site condominium plan, such as the following: repair and/or
replacement of all existing sidewalks on Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue
adjacent to the site; looping of proposed water mains into the existing water main for
Marais Avenue; and connecting storm water and sanitary sewers to the adjacent
G. Design Standards. Under §770-87 (D), Project Design Standards, any land use or a
combination of land uses may be approved by the Planning Commission in a Special
Redevelopment zoning district, provided such uses are consistent with the intent of
§770-87, including the qualifications for treatment as a Special Redevelopment project
H. Deviations from Required Standards. The Planning Commission may grant deviations
from applicable Zoning Ordinance standards as part of the approval for any Special
Redevelopment project under §770-87 (D)(1), provided there are features demonstrated
by the applicant and deemed adequate by the Commission that will protect surrounding
land uses and the general public health, safety, and welfare. Such deviations can be
granted for setbacks, parking and loading, general provisions, and other requirements.
Results of Approval. If approved, the special land use permit and any required conditions
would constitute the land use authorization for the property, and all improvement and
use would need to be in conformity with such authorization. Approval would remain valid
for a period of one year.
A development agreement prepared by the City Attorney is required as part of a final
plan approval under §770-87 (G) of the Zoning Ordinance. The agreement is required to
contain the basic terms and provisions of the approval, a clarification of the mutual
understanding with regard to the lawfulness of the development approval, and any
conditions imposed by the Planning Commission.
Approval of the development agreement by the City Commission would need to be a
required contingency of any special land use permit granted as part of a special
redevelopment project. If the petitioner’s request for a special land use permit is
approved, then preliminary site condominium plan review may proceed along with

i.b: Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

text.b: 5. Criteria for Special Land Use Permit & Special Redevelopment Project

page.text: The Planning Commission may grant, at its discretion, preliminary and/or final plan approval
for a Special Redevelopment project in the form of special land use permit. Following the
required public hearing, the Commission may approve, approve with conditions, or deny a
special land use permit for a preliminary and/or final Special Redevelopment plan.
The basis for the Planning Commission’s decision in the case of a special land use request
is found in §770-11 (C), Basis of Determinations, which reads as follows:

text.i: The Planning Commission shall review the proposed special land use in terms of the standards stated
within this Ordinance and shall establish that such use and the proposed location:
(a) Will be harmonious and in accordance with the general objectives or any specific objectives of the
Master Plan.
(b) Will be designed, constructed, operated, and maintained so as to be harmonious and appropriate in
appearance with the existing or intended character of the general vicinity and will not change the
essential character of the area.
(c) Will not be hazardous or disturbing to existing uses or uses reasonably anticipated in the future.
(d) Will be an improvement in relation to property in the immediate vicinity and to the City as a whole.
(e) Will be served adequately by essential public services and facilities or that the persons responsible
for the establishment of the proposed use will provide adequately any such service or facility.
Will not create excessive additional public costs and will not be detrimental to the economic welfare
of the City.
(g) Will be consistent with the intent and purposes of this Ordinance, and comply with all applicable
provisions and standards, which are established for said use by this Ordinance and other
applicable codes.

page.text: The qualifications for treatment of a Special Redevelopment project are found in § 770-87,
Special Redevelopment Projects, subparagraph (B)(1), which reads as follows:

text.i: The applicant shall demonstrate compliance § 770-11 (C), Basis of Determinations, for a special land
use permit, as well as the following:
(a) The existing structures on the property were initially constructed for hotel and/or motel use, public
schools, or other sites identified by the Planning Commission as possible for a special
redevelopment district.
(b) For hotels and/or motels, public schools and other sites as identified by the Planning Commission,
the applicant proposes to redevelop the property by removing or making material modifications,
discontinuing the existing use(s) on the property, and establishing a new use consistent with the
intent and provisions of this section.
(c) A recognizable and material benefit to the City will result from the redevelopment.
(d) The proposed use and improvements shall not result in an unreasonable increase in the need for or
burden upon public services, facilities, streets and utilities.
(e) The proposed use and improvements will result in an advantageous economic impact upon
surrounding properties.
The current structures on the property are materially nonconforming and/or the use is obsolete. For
the purposes of this subsection, obsolete are those hotels and motels existing or built prior to the
adoption of the chapter, those schools identified by the Royal Oak School Board as obsolete and
those properties identified by the Planning Commission as special redevelopment sites.
(g) The proposed use and improvements shall be consistent with the goals and policies of the Master
Plan and consistent with the intent of this section, as set forth in Subsection A, above.
(h) The proposed use is compatible with adjacent and nearby residential uses.

i.b: Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

page.text: The Planning Department recommends that the proposed preliminary special land use
permit and site condominium plan be denied by the Planning Commission due to the
The proposed site condominium plan is not consistent with the site’s future use of
“Public / Institutional” as designated on the Future Land Use Map of the city’s Master
Plan. The proposed site condominium plan is not consistent with the future land use of
“Public / Institutional” and “Parks & Open Space” for adjacent property as also
designated on the Future Land Use Map of the city’s Master Plan. The proposed
development therefore will not be harmonious and will change the character of the area.
The proposed site condominium plan would create an unplanned and isolated residential
development surrounded by heavily used athletic fields and recreational facilities. It is
the opinion of the Planning Department that if this site is developed as proposed future
property owners in this residential peninsula would complain about these existing uses
and related activities that surround the site.
The adjacent properties owned by the City of Royal Oak are designated as public parks
and can not be similarly developed without a public vote.
Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue in this area are predominately used by non-
residential traffic. The trip purposes are related to non-home based activities. On
numerous prior occasions the Planning Commission and City Commission have taken
steps to limit and/or restricted non-residential traffic from entering or impacting
residential neighborhoods. A few examples included Mohawk, Harrison, Lexington as
well as the numerous channelized driveways imposed by the Planning Commission and
residential parking permits granted by the City Commission. Approval of this
development would have the complete opposite result. It is reasonable to anticipate that
future conflicts will occur and create additional public costs.
If the Planning Commission agrees with the Planning Department’s recommendation it may
want to direct staff to prepare a “Finding of Facts” and denial resolution for the Commission
to consider at its March meeting.
However, should the Planning Commission disagree and wish to consider approval of the
preliminary special land use permit and site condominium plan, the Planning Department
suggests that the following issues be addressed within an application for final review:
A. An application for final special land use permit and special redevelopment site
condominium plan review shall be submitted within 6 months as required under § 770-87
B. All future use of each individual lot shall be limited to detached single-family dwellings or
another permitted use listed under § 770-34 (B) of the Zoning Ordinance.
C. All lots on the final site condominium plan shall comply with the minimum required lot
size standards of either the One Family Residential zoning district listed under § 770-34
(D)(1) to (3) of the Zoning Ordinance, or the One Family Large Lot Residential zoning
district listed under § 770-35 (D)(1) to (3) of the Zoning Ordinance.

i.b: Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

page.text: D. All dwellings shall comply with the minimum required and maximum permitted area and
bulk regulations either the One Family Residential zoning district listed under § 770-34
(D)(4) to (9) of the Zoning Ordinance, or the One Family Large Lot Residential zoning
district listed under § 770-35 (D)(4) to (9) of the Zoning Ordinance.
E. All accessory structures shall be placed within the rear yard of each lot and otherwise
comply with § 770-22 of the Zoning Ordinance. No dwelling shall have a front-loaded
F. All driveways shall have access to only Arbor Court or Marais Avenue. No new
driveways to Lexington Boulevard shall be permitted. Driveways for all lots adjacent to
Lexington Boulevard shall be placed along each lot’s south side lot line. Driveways and
accessory structures on adjacent lots should be placed along shared side lot lines
G. At least one large, deciduous canopy tree of a species listed in § 770-90 (K)(5) of the
Zoning Ordinance with a minimum caliper of 2.5 inches shall be placed in the right-of-
way curb lawn in front of each lot.
H. The proposed landscaped berm shown along west rear lot line within the petitioner’s
property boundaries shall be further detailed and identified on the final site condominium
plan in accordance with § 770-90 (D) of the Zoning Ordinance.
All utilities and improvements to the public rights-of-way shall be in accordance with the
specifications and standards of the City Engineer, including, but not limited to: repair
and/or replacement of existing sidewalks on Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue
adjacent to the site; connecting storm water and sanitary sewers to the adjacent
Oakland County drains; and looping proposed water mains into an existing the existing
water main on Marais Avenue. All electrical, telephone, cable television, and similar lines
J. Compliance with all other applicable provisions the Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 770
including § 770-14, Site Condominium Project Regulations), the Subdivision Regulations
Ordinance (Chapter 658), and the Michigan Land Division Act (Public Act 288 of 1967,
K. As part of the application for final special land use permit and special redevelopment site
condominium plan review, the petitioner shall also prepare and submit the following:
1) A traffic study so that the costs to mitigate impacts can be assigned to the
2) A construction staging plan for sales and/or construction trailers, off-street parking,
3) A special redevelopment agreement for the proposed project and final site
condominium plan for review by the City Attorney and approval by the City
The agreement shall contain a disclosure statement acknowledging and waiving any
rights regarding complaints about surrounding educational, recreational, and athletic

i.b: Special Land Use & Preliminary Special Redevelopment Site Condominium Plan

page.text: The disclosure statement shall also be included with the site condominium master
deed and recorded as a deed restriction for each individual lot.
cc: James V. Clarke, Robertson Brothers Co.
Brad W. Brickel, PE, Nowak & Fraus PLLC
Shawn Lewis-Lakins, Royal Oak School District

i.b: It is recommended that the petitioner or a representative attend the February 11, 2014 Planning Commission
meeting. The meeting starts at 7:30 p.m. in the City Commission Chambers on the 3rd floor of City Hall.

text.b: RE: 1123 Lexington Board of Education Offices
This development does not represent what RO is. We are chipping away at the integrity of our
city. It is poor Urban Planning, a bad location for residential homes, an uninspiring, cookie

page.text: This property is not like the other school properties which have been developed in RO. Those homes
were nestled within existing neighborhoods. Except for a couple of homes on Windemere there are
no other homes adjacent to this development, and will not serve to strengthen existing
neighborhoods. It is surrounded by recreation, the high school, baseball, tennis, running track,
soccer, ice arena and the Senior Center. It is the epicenter of one of Royal Oaks most valuable

text.b: This land is a rare gift to RO. It is relatively flat, no trees, pristine, and unique. It cannot be

page.text: duplicated anywhere in RO. You can undo a Starbucks, a Car Rental or even a Fresard Clock
Tower, but 36 homes will never go away. By building 36 homes, we are compromising the character
We are selling and developing property for a short term budgetary solution. The calculation of how
many children this will bring to RO schools is inflated. What will bring children to RO schools is
creating a full service, recreational/academic campus. If we want this for RO we are half way

text.b: there, and need to retain this 7.42 acres as public land to bring this full circle.
location in RO where this can happen.

page.text: People in Royal Oak are using services in other cities: parks in Clawson, the Auditorium at Clawson
school, tennis courts in Berkley, and the Pleasant Ridge Pool. We can put ourselves on the map as
one of the top small cities to live and visit, and live up to our reputation as “trendy” and “quaint”.
Robertson Brothers showed the plans to build 36 homes with 4 different facades. That means every
house is going to look identical.
In the backyard of these homes are the baseball diamonds with 96 metal halide, 100’ ft. lights, that
are going to be shining in their windows at night.
In August, the RO marching band practices for the games across the street from this development.
Labor Day weekend along Lexington, there are shuttle buses idling for 3 days in the street for Arts,
Beats and Eats along with parking in the baseball fields.
In the Fall for 6-7 months thru Winter, there is a 200’ft wide x 3 story high, white, tennis/soccer dome
in the backyard of these homes.
In September, the loud speakers announcing sporting events (football, lacrosse, soccer) from 8am to
10pm, all weekend and some week nights.
At the present time there is ”NO PARKING” on both sides of the 2
block of Marais. There will be 11
homes on Marais with no street parking.
The 3 homes planned (adjacent to the Windemere homes) are awkward. They are perpendicular to
existing garages. The entire property length on one side will view a masonry wall, and the view from
the street will be the side of the home.
Lexington Blvd. was recently rebuilt. Are construction trucks going to damage the new road? Who
will pay for repairs if necessary?

text.b: This Property is not suited for residential homes and should be utilized for the greater good of
Royal Oak’s History: What many people do not know…

page.text: Crooks and 13 Mile is one of the 1
settlements in all of Royal Oak. Cromwell Goodwin, a veteran of
the War of 1812, settled and farmed this property, including the 7.42 acres for sale, which he later
sold to his son and then to Joseph Folta.
Bob Mueller wrote a report, referring to this parcel where the Board of Ed is now. He states,
“The developing auto industry was drawing people from across the country to fill their factories.
Joseph Folta and Charter Oaks saw the need and opportunity. It could have been 50ft. lots with
houses and streets. It didn’t happen. The Great Depression stopped the growth and Charter
Oaks land was lost to the State of MI. During WWII, the land was transferred from the State to the
City of RO. With the end of the war and the baby boom, the City needed another high school and
more parks. This chain of events limited the number of buildings placed upon this land and
gave us a gift we have all failed to see before. If you stand on Crooks Rd. just N. of the high
school, you can easily visualize Cromwell’s farm. Nowhere else in the city is it possible to still

text.b: imagine seeing a farm from the 1800’s.”

page.text: In 1957, the 7.42 acres of City owned land was acquired by the School District. The intent of this land
was to be used for “the good of the people of the City”, and at that point in time there was a need for
school related structures. Now it is being sold to build privately owned houses. It is as if you give
your neighbor your old leaf blower because he only has a rake, and he turns around and sells it in a
yard sale and keeps the rake. The intent was not for your neighbor to make money off your leaf
blower. The intent of these 7.42 is to serve all RO residents. Whether it is city or school owned, it was
still payed for with tax payer dollars. When this land was first purchased in the 1800’s these 7.42
acres cost less than $10. Real Estate is a good investment for the city.
At the last PC mtg. on May 13
, Mayor Ellison was visibly distressed at the fact that he had to
approve a Fireworks store. That is how I and a great many neighbors feel about this development.
The difference is there is a chance the firework law could be repealed or the firework store may move

text.b: How Can the City Acquire the Land:
Has the city even tried to buy this land?

page.text: It concerns me greatly, with all the large construction projects planned for RO, this one is slipping
through the cracks and not being given the due diligence it requires. At $1.6 million with 28,000
households it would cost a onetime millage of $56/household to purchase. If you want to demo the
existing building round up to $60/household. Not to mention donations, grants, philanthropic money,
Have any of these ideas even been looked into? Have we even asked the residents if they want this
land back? Why can’t we take a couple months, count to 10, and explore this option.
It was said at the last meeting this was the best offer we were going to get. Are we are aiming for
mediocrity instead of striving for excellence? What if you would have said that about the Kroger
on Main St. you wouldn’t have an awesome hotel going in that we desperately need.
We temporarily lease the space, like what is done at Memorial Park or Total Soccer until the funds
A premiere Recreation/Park epicenter. A bike track, which had been vocalized as a need for Royal
Oak for years. The inner circle a running/walking track, a pavilion, picnic tables, an urban garden or
forest, plants that reflect all the species native to MI. A fountain that would duo as a splash pad,
handicapped accessible playground (no purple dinosaurs), volleyball, basketball courts, chess tables,
possibly a pool, outdoor ice skating, and of course parking. There could also be a space for urban
camping for the Scout groups tied in with the Tenhave Woods. Last but not least as homage to our
first RO settler, Cromwell Goodwin, build a replica of his 1800’s farmhouse, where Bob Mueller can
do nature/history talks. Schools could come on field trips, a learning center, or just as a meeting room

text.b: This is a critical decision which will impact all of RO for years to come. Are we certain that

page.text: Anne Vaara; Clyde Esbri; Dan; Commissioner David Poulton; Gary D. Quesada; Jeffery R. Chase;
I will not be able to attend the meeting on 6/10/2014 when the review for the site plan for the site where
the current Royal Oak Schools offices will be conducted. I have follwed the developments on this
property and believe the plan for quality single family homes is the best use for this property. I live at
127 Maxwell Ave, a site developed under a similar plan. The school system has been transparent in the
development of its need to "right size" and converting the excess properties to community best use,
while capitalizing on the need for additional quality housing in Royal Oak. For these reasons, I ask that
you share my support of the plan under consideration with the planning board members.
Sent from my Verizon Wireless 4G LTE Tablet
Anne Vaara; Clyde Esbri; Dan; Commissioner David Poulton; Gary D. Quesada; Jeffery R. Chase;
Make sure this is sent to the Planning Commission, as it is on their agenda tonight. I am copying the Planning
I'm writing to ask that the Lexington development be voted down. I live on West Windemere and am
concerned about a few things. I feel 36 homes packed into that tiny are is too many and frankly, tacky.
My wife works midnights and shouldn't have to be woken up by construction noise. I'm also very
concerned about the 72 additional vehicles 36 homes would put on our street. Lexington is already
congested from school traffic so the 72 additional vehicles would inevitably pour onto West Windemere.
I urge you to vote against this development.
Robertson Brothers Residential TIA FINAL Memo 4-14-14
This memorandum presents the results of a Traffic Impact Assessment (TIA) for the proposed residential
development in the City of Royal Oak, Michigan. The project site is located on the southwest corner of
Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue (the former Royal Oak Public Schools administration building site)
and is proposed to include 36 single family units. Site access for 26 units will be provided via site roads to
Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue with the remaining units to be accessed via individual driveways
The purpose of this TIA is to evaluate traffic operations with the proposed project at the following study
The scope of the study was developed based on Fleis & VandenBrink’s (F&V) knowledge of the study area,
understanding of the development program, accepted traffic engineering practice, and methodologies
published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE). Input and agreement on the study scope was
also achieved through conversations with the City of Royal Oak. The study analyses were completed using
Synchro and SimTraffic (Version 8) traffic analysis software.
Existing traffic volume data were collected at the study intersections by F&V subconsultant Traffic Data
Collection, Inc. (TDC). Vehicular turning movement count data were collected in 15-minute intervals on April
, 2014 between the hours of 7:00 AM to 9:00 AM and 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM. Additionally, 24-hour
volume data was collected on the study roadways in order to identify the peak periods of traffic to be
analyzed. Lastly, F&V collected an inventory of existing lane use and traffic controls and obtained traffic
signal timing information from the City of Royal Oak. The applicable data referenced in this memorandum are
Robertson Brothers Residential TIA FINAL Memo 4-14-14
The existing AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes were identified based on the data collected. Peak hour
volumes for each intersection were used and through volumes were balanced upward through the study
network. At locations where access is provided between study intersections, “dummy” intersections were
used to account for sink and source volumes, and through volumes were carried along the main study
Existing peak hour vehicle delays and Levels of Service (LOS) were calculated based on the existing lane use
and traffic control, the existing peak hour traffic volumes, and the methodologies presented in the Highway
Capacity Manual, 2000 (HCM). Typically, LOS D is considered acceptable, with LOS A representing minimal
delay, and LOS F indicating failing conditions. Additionally, SimTraffic network simulations were reviewed to
evaluate network operations and vehicle queues. The results of the existing conditions analysis are attached
Robertson Brothers Residential TIA FINAL Memo 4-14-14
The results of the existing conditions analysis indicate that all study intersection approaches and movements
currently operate acceptably at a LOS D or better during both peak periods. Additionally, study network
operations were simulated to evaluate vehicle queues. Observation of the network simulation indicates
overall acceptable operations during the peak hours. At the signalized intersection of Crooks Road &
Lexington Boulevard, moderate vehicle queues are observed during the AM peak hour. However, these
queues dissipate and are not present throughout the duration of the peak hour.
In order to determine the applicable traffic growth rate for the existing traffic volumes to project build-out, the
24-hour traffic counts collected by F&V were compared to SEMCOG historical traffic data. The results of this
analysis indicate that traffic volumes in the study area have remained constant or declined. Consistent with
stagnant traffic growth patterns throughout southeast Michigan, the background growth rate was assumed to
be zero percent for this study. Therefore, background conditions without the proposed developments are
assumed to be equal to existing conditions.
The number of AM and PM peak hour vehicle trips that would be generated by the proposed residential
development was forecast based on data published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) in Trip

text.i: Generation, 9
th

page.text: The vehicle trips shown in Table 2 were assigned to the study road network based on existing peak hour
traffic patterns, the proposed site plan, and the driver’s perception of the easiest route of travel over various
sections of the road network. The site-generated vehicle trips were assigned to the study road network based
on the trip distribution patterns outlined in Table 3 and was added to the existing traffic volumes to calculate
the total future peak hour traffic volumes.
Robertson Brothers Residential TIA FINAL Memo 4-14-14
The site-generated trip assignments were added to the existing traffic volumes to determine the total future
peak hour traffic volumes with the proposed development. Future peak hour vehicle delays and LOS were
calculated at the study intersections based on these volumes and the existing intersection lane use and traffic
Robertson Brothers Residential TIA FINAL Memo 4-14-14
The results of this analysis indicate that the proposed project would have a negligible impact on vehicle
delays experienced at the study intersections. Future vehicle delays and LOS as shown in Table 4 would be
similar to existing conditions and increases in vehicle delay would not be discernable. Additionally, traffic at
the signalized intersections of Crooks Road & Lexington Boulevard and 13 Mile Road & Marais Avenue will
increase by less than 1% during both peak hours which is not significant. At the proposed site access points
to Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue, all movements would operate at a LOS C or better during both
peak hours. Review of the network simulations also indicates acceptable operations, and vehicle queues are
The conclusions of this Traffic Impact Assessment are as follows:
1. Currently, all study intersection approaches and movements operate acceptably at a LOS D or better
2. The proposed development would have a negligible impact on the study road network.
3. The proposed site access points with Lexington Boulevard and Marais Avenue will operate
Any questions related to this memorandum, study, analyses, and results should be addressed to Fleis &
